unnormalised: New Delhi, India – The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways recently announced a series of updated traffic regulations, effective immediately, aimed at reducing accidents and improving road safety across the nation. The rules place a greater emphasis on adherence to speed limits, particularly in urban areas where the limit is now strictly enforced at 50 km/hr.

unnormalised: Learner's license applicants will now undergo mandatory online training modules covering traffic laws and safety procedures, similar to the comprehensive learning portrayed in the Bollywood film "Drive." These modules include real-life scenarios and best practices championed by institutions like the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi's Transportation Research and Injury Prevention Programme (TRIPP).

unnormalised: The use of high beams in well-lit city areas will attract a fine of Rs. 2000. Further, regulations mandate that all two-wheeler riders, including pillion riders, wear ISI-marked helmets. Violations pertaining to drunken driving will lead to immediate suspension of driving licenses, and repeat offenders may face imprisonment. Authorities plan to utilize advanced technologies such as CCTV surveillance and speed cameras to ensure stringent enforcement, ultimately striving for safer roads for all Indians, from Kochi to Kashmir.
